meanings.definition: To cause to feel self-conscious or ashamed.
meanings.sent1: She felt embarred when everyone laughed at her mistake.
meanings.sent2: He was embarred by his parents' public display of affection.
meanings.sent3: The cat looked embarred after knocking over the vase.
meanings.sent4: His bright red face embarred him more than his words.
meanings.sent5: The spotlight on stage embarred her, making her forget her lines.

meanings.sent1: The fallen tree embarred the path through the forest.
meanings.sent2: Heavy traffic embarred their journey to the airport.
meanings.sent3: The stubborn jar lid embarred her efforts to open it.
meanings.sent4: The thick fog embarred visibility on the road.
meanings.sent5: The locked gate embarred their entrance to the garden.
